title: Indian Sweets & Mithai
short_description: India's vast repertoire of desserts, from syrup-soaked Gulab Jamuns to milk-based Rasgullas and nutty Barfes.
long_description:
In India, sweets (Mithai) are not just dessert; they are an auspicious offering to gods, a gesture of hospitality, and a symbol of celebration. The variety is staggering, ranging from the milk-based sweets of Bengal (Chenna) to the ghee and flour-based indulgences of the North and the jaggery-coconut treats of the South.

Key ingredients include milk (khoa), ghee, sugar, jaggery, nuts, and aromatic spices like cardamom, saffron, and rose water. Every festival puts a spotlight on specific sweets.

signature_dishes.name: Gulab Jamun
signature_dishes.short_description: Deep-fried milk solid balls soaked in a rose-scented sugar syrup.

signature_dishes.name: Rasgulla
signature_dishes.short_description: Spongy cottage cheese balls cooked in a light sugar syrup. Originating from East India.

signature_dishes.name: Jalebi
signature_dishes.short_description: Crispy, spiral-shaped fried batter soaked in syrup. Often eaten for breakfast with milk or curd.

signature_dishes.name: Kaju Katli
signature_dishes.short_description: Diamond-shaped cashew fudge, a favorite for gifting during Diwali.

signature_dishes.name: Mysore Pak
signature_dishes.short_description: A rich, melting sweet made of gram flour, generous amounts of ghee, and sugar.

top_restaurants.name: Haldiram's
top_restaurants.notes: Reliable hygiene and standard taste for most North Indian sweets.

top_restaurants.name: K.C. Das
top_restaurants.notes: Inventors of the canned Rasgulla tradition.

top_restaurants.name: Balaram Mullick & Radharaman Mullick
top_restaurants.notes: Famous for innovative baked sweets and traditional Bengali mithai.

best_markets_and_streets.name: Chandni Chowk
best_markets_and_streets.what_to_try: Jalebi at Old Famous Jalebi Wala.

food_festivals.name: Diwali
food_festivals.description: The festival of lights is synonymous with exchanging boxes of sweets (Mithai).

dining_etiquette: Sweets are often eaten with hands. It is polite to accept a sweet when offered as a sign of celebration.
seasonal_specialties: Gajar Ka Halwa (Carrot Pudding) in winter.
recommended_precautions_for_travellers: Milk-based sweets have a short shelf life. Consume fresh.
